comments:
Frequently as I edit JSP files I receive a dialog with the error:
An internal error occurred during: "Processing Dirty Regions".

From the stack trace (below), it looks like there is a problem handling an
include
"...core.internal.java.JSPTranslator.handleIncludeFile(JSPTranslator.java:1389)"

This error forces me to restart Eclipse. The files no longer deploy...

Created an attachment (id=24676)
Full error log related to bug
David, in which build did you see this?

(In reply to comment #2)
> David, in which build did you see this?


Hi

Version: 0.7.0
Build id: 200507061517

I'm also seeing this error, in 0.7RC1. Following your EJB tutorial, Naci, and
creating  the new file test.jsp.

We need to get to the bottom of this. 
I've alwasy been curious Phil ... why does an error dialog pop up ... seems even
if an error occurs, is there some way we can silently ignore, and just "flag"
that we need to re-process for validation?

I agree that the error popup from uncaught exception in the job is a bit
obnoxious.  It might be better just to catch the exception and log it.

We probably don't want to "force" revalidation (from the catch), because it's
likely that the thing that caused exception still isn't fixed, so that would
cause an infinite loop.

In any case we can do someting smarter/more discrete.

The root of this particular problem still needs to be investigated, especially
if it's a tutorial that people are expected to follow.  I'll try to reproduce.

(In reply to comment #4)

they are supposed to test against java1.4.2...

I am getting a similar problem editing an xml file.

Using Eclipse 3.1.1 and WST 0.7.0 I was fine yesterday, but upon loading Eclipse
an editing the xml file today I got the following errors (below)

Note there are two errors - one for not being able to load the DTD file (???)
and then the one related to this bug. I included the first error incase it is
related and adds useful information.

Note that I also only upgraded to Eclipse 3.1.1 a couple of days ago - I have
been using WST 0.7.0 for quite a while longer. This is the first time I have
seen this bug, and I work on this xml file almost every day. I have been running
Eclipse under Java 1.5.0_x - but trying it now under 1.4.2_07 I still get the
same problem.

(In reply to comment #8)
> I was having this problem too until I moved back to java1.4.2_x. I think that is
> the issue. That may also explain why many of the developers don't see it since
> they are supposed to test against java1.4.2...
>

Ben, the errors you're running into are more likely due to having an old
org.eclipse.wst.common.uriresolver plugin compared to the rest of WST. 
NoClassDefFoundErrors and especially NoSuchMethodErrors point to runtime
mismatches in versions of code.

I am also having this same problem. It seems to only occur on while editing very
large xml files.

The error starting appearing when the xml file got around 1500 lines. As the xml
file's size increased, the frequency of the error message occurance increased.
The xml file is now around 3000 lines and the error message is making it almost
completely uneditable.

Also, pertaining to the error's frequency of occurence: Before I did a full
update to all installed eclipse components today the error would only occur with
editing a start or end tags of an xml elements with a large number sibling
elements (around 600 or so). The error would not occur when there were moderate
to low amount of sibling elements (say 100 or less).

After todays rounds of updating, the error now occurs when editing any element
within the xml file. Also a second error occurs moments after the "Processing
Dirty Regions" error. The second error reads "Loading referenced grammars".

If you need a copy of the xml file let me know.

Hi,

I'm still getting this one on a recent 1.0.1 M build.  Quite surprised to see it's not targetted.  Surely it's a big enough bug that there should be a JUnit test...

It doesn't seem to be just down to one file of a given size... as I'd not seen it for a while, and then it reappeared.

Other members of the team here don't see it so often... although they did find it quite amusing when I asked "do you get an Error Processing Dirty Regions"... :O)

Cheers,

Neale

I'm now getting this consistently with the latest declared 1.0.1 build, as follows:

My stack traces show that my errors are coming from the following:
  java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: javax/servlet/jsp/tagext/TagLibraryInfo

So it could be that there's more than one bug.  

This simple file causes the error when opening the file:

<%@ taglib uri="/WEB-INF/struts-tiles.tld" prefix="tiles" %>

<tiles:insert definition="profilenotapproved" />
<tiles:insert definition="profilenotvisible" />
<tiles:insert definition="viewed"/>

and then when I save a change (add whitespace in this test case) I get a "Updating JSP Index" internal error.

The stack traces are:

(In reply to comment #14)
> I'm now getting this consistently with the latest declared 1.0.1 build, as
> follows:
> 
> My stack traces show that my errors are coming from the following:
>   java.lang.NoClassDefFoundError: javax/servlet/jsp/tagext/TagLibraryInfo
> 

Neale, well, technically we have not declared a 101 build yet :) 
I assume you mean latest M build on /committers/ downloads? 

Do you have any "old" WTP plugins still installed, like from SDK 0.7.1? 

Have you tried with a fresh install of dev. env? 

Did you use -clean after you upgraded to 101 stream? Did you install on top of a 1.0 environment? Or start afresh?  

Do you have a server associated with the project? If wo, which one? 
(I'm wondering if there's some servers that do not provide this interface?)

Nitin or Phil, 
perhaps we should isolate the failure in a tiny try/catch block (and log it missing just once), so if no server provides this interface we at least don't "fail".

Neale, we'll target to 101 if we can reproduce, but this is a bit of a mystery to us.

The one place where we use these "optional" server classes is:

JSPTranslator.addTaglibVariables(JSPTranslator.java:623)

maybe we should but the try/catch (and log missing class once) there.

Taglib bug seems to be seperate one from this bug, originally reported in bug #119144.

In answer to David's questions, I dropped the latest (non-declared) build over 1.0.  I've since done a complete clean out of wst and jst jars and folders from apps/{plugins,features,configuration} but to no avail.

I'm doing a -clean EVERY time I lauch WTP as standard.

Additionally, what I've done is delete the whole of .metadata and re-import.

I suspect that there is something seriously wrong if I cannot clean out *.jst.* and *.wst.* from plugins and configuration and do an "eclipse -clean".  

Is there something that I'm missing that means I've got to continually start a fresh workspace and fresh Eclipse install, including re-installing SVN each time ??!



The project causing the problems has facets stating that it is a Dynamic Web Project: 2.4. 

As WTP is supposed to be allowing us to develop to open standards, then surely I shouldn't need a deployable server available just to do development.

Phillip suggests catching the exception... I'm all in favor of that, if someone could say what functionality is being provided by the optional components.

Neile, just to comment .. its general not a good idea to install one build "on top" of another. Better to do to a fresh location. 

And, please confirm, you do not uninstall anything else? Such as "the help system" which contains an old version of Apache Tomcat? 

I'm also wondering if SVN installs some part of the server runtime If you get a chance, you might check if "javax/servlet/jsp/tagext/TagLibraryInfo" is anywhere on your system. If not, you might include a URL here where we could get the SVN plugin you are using. 

Lastly, the reason we often require a runtime server to be installed is because otherwise we'd have to distribute much of the "J2EE Standard Interfaces" that come with J2EE Runtimes. Its both easier to get from the server runtime, more accurate, and there's less legal stuff to do. 

The functionality is pretty important, for those that want content assist for UseBeans, etc. So, I would like to understand exactly why you get this, instead of just catching the exception and log it. Of course, one we understand it, we might decide catching it and ignoring it (or, logging it) is the best course of action. But ... sounds like somethng else is wrong.

Mike do you also develop with no target server defined in your workbench? 
If so, an easy fix for now would be to just define some generic j2ee server and associate it to your project. 

Have you tried using -clean when you first start Eclipse? 

You do have 3.1.2 installed, right? 

It would help if you attached whole configuration properties, if possible.

> It would help if you attached whole configuration properties, if possible.

I'm attaching \eclipse\configuration\config.ini. Is that what you mean?

# Eclipse runtime configuration file
# This file contains a number of key/value pairs that are merged into the 
# System properties on system startup.  The values control the way the 
# runtime is structured and runs.

# Note:  Only platform:/base/ and file: URLs are supported.  In general the 
# URLs given may include a version number (e.g., .../location_1.2.3).  
# If a version is not specified, the system binds
# to the location which matches exactly or to the versioned location with the
# latest version number.  If a version number is given then only exact matches
# are considered.

# The URL for the runtime entry point.  The default value is
# platform:/base/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi 
#osgi.framework = platform:/base/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi

# The classpath for the framework found at the osgi.framework location.  This 
# comma-separated list contains either URLs or simple element names.  Simple
# names are assumed to be relative to the framework's install directory.  
# Typically this value need not be set as it is initialized by the framework itself.
# Version match searching is not done for URLs listed here.
#osgi.frameworkClassPath =

# The comma-separated list of locations to search for the splash screen file (splash.bmp).
# For each list element a subdirectory structure based on the pattern nl/<locale> is searched.
# The system binds to the first matching file.  There is no default value.
osgi.splashPath = platform:/base/plugins/org.eclipse.platform

# The location of the splash screen file.  If this value is set at system startup it is used 
# in favour of the osgi.splashPath searching outlined above.  If the value is not set 
# the searching is done and this key is bound to the result of the search.
#osgi.splashLocation =

# The comma-separated list of bundles which are automatically installed and optionally started
# once the system is up and running.  Each entry if of the form
#     <URL | simple bundle location>[@ [<startlevel>] [":start"]]
# If the startlevel is omitted then the framework will use the default start level for the bundle.
# If the "start" tag is added then the bundle will be marked as started after being installed.
# Simple bundle locations are interepreted as relative to the framework's parent directory.
# The startlevel indicates the OSGi start level at which the bundle should run.
# If this value is not set, the system computes an appropriate default.
osgi.bundles=org.eclipse.equinox.common@2:start, org.eclipse.update.configurator@3:start, org.eclipse.core.runtime@start

# The product to run.  A given Eclipse configuration may contain many products.
# The product identified will supply the branding (window icons, title bar text) etc 
# as well as define the default application to run.  
eclipse.product=org.eclipse.sdk.ide

# The application to run.  The value specified here is the id of the application extension
# the runtime will find, instantiate and execute once the system is up.  Note that typically 
# the identified eclipse.product defines the default application to run.
#eclipse.application=

# The default workspace location
osgi.instance.area.default=@user.home/workspace

# The build identifier
eclipse.buildId=I20060413-1718


# End of file marker - must be here
eof=eof

For those of you finding this problem on "RC1" of eclipse then 
  1. you should not try using RC1 with WTP .. RC1a, maybe. 
  2. which version of WTP are you using? I thought WTP RC1a should have "had the fix" related to servet api, but if you have an "older" verison of WTP, then that would explain why you are seeing this now. 

Someone needs to sort though this bug now, and see which are related to RC1 issues, and which other issues.

-Tim

(In reply to comment #28)
Joshua, you should really use the corresponding WTP 1.5 RC when using an Eclipse 3.2 RC.  WTP 0.7.x and 1.0.x will be incompatible with Eclipse 3.2 RC1 and newer because of changes to the help plugins (see bug 130292) and the way those versions of the JSP component were written.

(In reply to comment #29)
While you are, of course, correct in saying we should use WTP 1.5 RC when using an Eclipse 3.2 RC, I can confirm that this setup also has the bug. I am using
Eclipse 3.2.0.v20060404 with
WST 1.5.0.v200604022030
and have the same problem.

preferably with sample files.
